Active Membership Inference Attack under Local Differential Privacy in Federated Learning

Abstract

Federated learning (FL) was originally regarded as a framework for collaborative learning among clients with data privacy protection through a coordinating server. In this paper, we propose a new active membership inference (AMI) attack carried out by a dishonest server in FL. In AMI attacks, the server crafts and embeds malicious parameters into global models to effectively infer whether a target data sample is included in a clientâ€™s private training data or not. By exploiting the correlation among data features through a non-linear decision boundary, AMI attacks with a certified guarantee of success can achieve severely high success rates under rigorous local differential privacy (LDP) protection; thereby exposing clientsâ€™ training data to significant privacy risk. Theoretical and experimental results on several benchmark datasets show that adding sufficient privacy-preserving noise to prevent our attack would significantly damage FLâ€™s model utility.

1 INTRODUCTION

Federated Learning (FL) has emerged as a promising large-scale collaborative learning framework in recent years. By design, FL enables participating clients to collaboratively train a global model through a coordinating server. Although training data never leaves clientsâ€™ devices, a dishonest server can still infer the membership information of any clientâ€™s training data through observing their local model updates by using (passive or active) membership inference attacks [Shokri etÂ al., 2017, Salem etÂ al., 2019, Song and Mittal, 2021, Nasr etÂ al., 2019]. For that reason, FL in its primitive form offers little to no privacy protection.

To address the problem, several privacy-preserving mechanisms, such as local differential privacy (LDP), have been developed to challenge membership inference (MI) attacks in general and active membership inference (AMI) attacks in particular by effectively protecting the membership information of clientâ€™s training data with upper-bounded privacy leakage [Arachchige etÂ al., 2019, Sun etÂ al., 2021, Lai etÂ al., 2021, Lyu etÂ al., 2020]. Recent studies apparently show that LDP protection is effective in mitigating MI and AMI attacks [Rahman etÂ al., 2018, Bernau etÂ al., 2021, Gu etÂ al., 2022]. The key reason for this result is that existing attacks have not fully conveyed privacy risks in FL by under-exploiting the correlation among data features and LDP protection. That poses previously unexplored privacy risk to the clientsâ€™ local training data.

Key Contributions. To tackle that problem, we first formalize a new AMI threat model equipped with an AMI attack from a dishonest server. The key idea is that, given a target data sample, the server carefully crafts malicious weights of the global model such that the model updates from the clients would expose the membership information of the target data sample through the behavior of a chosen neuron. A chosen neuron is only activated given the target data sample controlled by a non-linear decision boundary embedded inside the malicious weights. With our non-linear decision boundary, the server can infer this membership information with severely high success rates. Furthermore, the server effortlessly achieves this result with a minimal change to the global model parameters within one training iteration.

In addition, we take a step forward and devise an AMI attack strategy under LDP protection to significantly amplify the privacy risk in FL. By adding a certain amount of privacy-preserving noise to the local data before training, LDP can protect the data with formal privacy leakage bounds (controlled by a privacy budget Îµğœ€\varepsilon) [Dwork etÂ al., 2014]. The key advantage of our AMI attack is exploiting the correlation among data features to distinguish the target data sample from others under LDP protection (Eq. 7). If LDP-preserving noise is insufficient to break this correlation (i.e., large privacy budgets Îµğœ€\varepsilon), clientsâ€™ local data will be at risk of our AMI attack with certified guarantees of success. Meanwhile, large privacy-preserving noise (i.e., small privacy budgets Îµğœ€\varepsilon) can significantly damage the FLâ€™s model utility.

Our theoretical and experimental results in many benchmark datasets show that our AMI attacks stress-test the fundamental trade-offs between model utility and privacy risk in FL to a new level. This is reflected through notably high success rates under rigorous LDP protection (i.e., small privacy budgets Îµğœ€\varepsilon which significantly degenerate FLâ€™s model utility).

Organization.

The remainder of the paper is structured as follows. Section 2 presents background and establishes our threat model. Section 3 introduces our AMI attack from a dishonest server in FL. We devise an attack strategy under LDP protection with certified guarantees of success in Section 4. Section 5 evaluates the performance of AMI attacks in several benchmark datasets. Section 6 discusses related work and Section 7 provides concluding remarks.

2 BACKGROUND AND THREAT MODEL

In this section, we briefly review the background of federated learning and differential privacy, and then introduce our active membership inference threat model.

2.1 Background

Federated Learning (FL).

We focus on a horizontal setting of FL in which different clients hold the same set of features but different sets of samples. FL with Local Differential Privacy (LDP).

Recent attacks have shown that clientsâ€™ training data samples can be extracted from the shared gradients [Zhu etÂ al., 2019, Yin etÂ al., 2021]. These attacks underscore privacy risks in FL. Therefore, privacy-preserving mechanisms are needed to control and mitigate the privacy risks introduced by gradient sharing while optimizing utility.

Local differential privacy (LDP) [Dwork etÂ al., 2006, Erlingsson etÂ al., 2014] is one of the auspicious solutions, given its formal protection without an undue sacrifice in computation efficiency. LDP builds on the ideas of randomized response [Warner, 1965], which was initially introduced to allow survey respondents to provide their inputs while maintaining their confidentiality. The definition of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon-LDP is as follows:

Definition 1.

The privacy budget Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon controls the amount by which the distributions induced by inputs xğ‘¥x and xâ€²superscriptğ‘¥â€²x^{\prime} may differ. A smaller value of Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon enforces a stronger privacy guarantee but reduces model utility.

2.2 Active Membership Inference Threat Model

Previous studies typically focus on a scenario in which the central server is interested in uncovering client information by examining local updates from the clients, but still abiding by the system protocol. This threat model is commonly referred to as honest-but-curious or semi-honest. However, this threat model undermines the vulnerability of the FL system as in practice, the server can deviate from the protocol to strengthen the privacy attacks [Boenisch etÂ al., 2021, Nguyen etÂ al., 2022, Fowl etÂ al., 2021]. In this work, we are thus interested in explicitly malicious (or actively dishonest) servers that may modify the model architecture and/or model parameters before dispatching them to the clients. In this regard, we propose an active membership inference threat model, in which a dishonest server maliciously adjusts the model parameters to determine whether a target data sample is in the local training dataset of a client.

We describe the active membership inference threat model as follows. We denote ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} as the central server in FL, which is also the adversary. Note that this threat model represents an attack at an arbitrary iteration that targets a specific client. Let ğ’Ÿ={(xi,yi)}ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–\mathcal{D}=\{(x_{i},y_{i})\} be the batch of training data of the target client. The set ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D} contains sample xiâˆˆâ„dsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and its ground-truth label yiâˆˆ{1,â€¦,k}subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–1â€¦ğ‘˜y_{i}\in\{1,...,k\} with kğ‘˜k classes. Suppose that ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D} is sampled from a distribution ğ”»ğ”»\mathbb{D} on (xi,yi)subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–(x_{i},y_{i}) that the adversary ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} has knowledge of (i.e., similar to existing studies [Carlini etÂ al., 2022, Yeom etÂ al., 2018, Shokri etÂ al., 2017]). This is practical in the real world since the server can collect a massive amount of data that covers the local data distribution of a sufficient number of clients [Shokri etÂ al., 2017]. The adversary outputs maliciously crafted model parameters Î¸ğœƒ\theta to the target client. The client sends the local gradients G=âˆ‡Î¸â„’â€‹(ğ’Ÿ,Î¸)ğºsubscriptâˆ‡ğœƒâ„’ğ’ŸğœƒG=\nabla_{\theta}\mathcal{L}({\cal D},\theta) back to the adversary. By observing the local gradients GğºG, the goal of the serverâ€™s attack is to determine whether a target (data) sample tâˆˆâ„dğ‘¡superscriptâ„ğ‘‘t\in\mathbb{R}^{d} is included in the local training set ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D}. More formally, the adversary can be defined as the following function:

ğ’œğ”»:t,Gâ†’{0,1}:superscriptğ’œğ”»â†’ğ‘¡ğº01\mathcal{A}^{\mathbb{D}}:t,G\rightarrow\{0,1\} (2)

3 ACTIVE MEMBERSHIP INFERENCE (AMI) ATTACK

This section first discusses the technical intuition of membership inference through gradients. Based on this concept, we then describe our proposed strategy to launch the AMI attack from a dishonest server.

3.1 Inferring Membership via Gradients

As shown in Fig. 1, the adversary ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} receives the gradients GğºG that was computed on the training set ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D}, and ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} wishes to determine whether tâˆˆğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ’Ÿt\in{\cal D}. This section discusses how the membership information can be inferred through gradients.

Suppose that, on an input data point xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, the output of the first fully-connected layer is expressed as ReLUâ¡(Wâ€‹x+b)=maxâ¡(0,Wâ€‹x+b)ReLUğ‘Šğ‘¥ğ‘0ğ‘Šğ‘¥ğ‘\operatorname{ReLU}(Wx+b)=\max(0,Wx+b) where Wâˆˆâ„rÃ—dğ‘Šsuperscriptâ„ğ‘Ÿğ‘‘W\in\mathbb{R}^{r\times d} is the weight matrix of that layer and bâˆˆâ„rğ‘superscriptâ„ğ‘Ÿb\in\mathbb{R}^{r} is the bias vector (rğ‘Ÿr is the number of neurons in the layer). To express the output of the iğ‘–i-th neuron of that layer, we denote Wisubscriptğ‘Šğ‘–W_{i} as the corresponding row in the weight matrix and bisubscriptğ‘ğ‘–b_{i} as the corresponding component in the bias vector. We observe that, when Wiâ€‹x+biâ‰¤0subscriptğ‘Šğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘–0W_{i}x+b_{i}\leq 0, the ReLU outputs zero, in other words, the neuron iğ‘–i is not activated by xğ‘¥x. As a result, the gradient of neuron iğ‘–i, denoted by Gi(x)subscriptsuperscriptğºğ‘¥ğ‘–G^{(x)}_{i}, is zero at the data point xğ‘¥x. Otherwise, when Wiâ€‹x+bi>0subscriptğ‘Šğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ğ‘–0W_{i}x+b_{i}>0, the gradient Gi(x)subscriptsuperscriptğºğ‘¥ğ‘–G^{(x)}_{i} is non-zero.

As the gradient GğºG is computed over the whole training set ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D}, the gradient of a neuron iğ‘–i received by the adversary is the average of gradients over all data points xâˆˆğ’Ÿğ‘¥ğ’Ÿx\in{\cal D}, i.e., Gi=1|ğ’Ÿ|â€‹âˆ‘xâˆˆğ’ŸGi(x)subscriptğºğ‘–1ğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘¥ğ’Ÿsubscriptsuperscriptğºğ‘¥ğ‘–G_{i}=\frac{1}{|{\cal D}|}\sum_{x\in{\cal D}}G^{(x)}_{i}. {âˆ‘j=1dWiâ€‹jâ€‹tj>0âˆ‘j=1dWiâ€‹jâ€‹xjâ‰¤0,âˆ€xâˆˆğ’Ÿâˆ–t\left\{\begin{aligned} &\sum_{j=1}^{d}W_{ij}t_{j}>0\\ &\sum_{j=1}^{d}W_{ij}x_{j}\leq 0,\quad\forall x\in{\cal D}\setminus t\end{aligned}\right. (4)

note that we suppress the bias term for simplicity.

If tâˆˆğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ’Ÿt\in{\cal D}, then Gisubscriptğºğ‘–G_{i} will be non-zero; otherwise, tâˆ‰ğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ’Ÿt\notin{\cal D} results in Gisubscriptğºğ‘–G_{i} being zero. From that, the adversary upon seeing Gisubscriptğºğ‘–G_{i} can easily infer whether the target data sample tğ‘¡t was a part of the training set ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D} or not. The formulation in Eq. (4) is similar to the framework proposed by [Boenisch etÂ al., 2021] for conducting data reconstruction attacks where a neuron that is activated only by one sample can be used to perfectly reconstruct that sample. However, we shall see below that this simple formulation is actually inapplicable to the membership inference attack, thus requiring a more advanced strategy to launch the attack.

3.2 Attack Strategy: Manipulating Model Parameters via Training a Chosen Neuron

As aforementioned, if there exists a neuron that is activated only by the target data sample tğ‘¡t, it is sufficient to determine whether tğ‘¡t is in the training set ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D} or not. From the threat model, the adversary can determine the model parameters Î¸ğœƒ\theta, which includes the weight matrix Wğ‘ŠW. Obviously, the adversary can choose some neuron iğ‘–i and try to solve Eq. (4) for Wğ‘ŠW to realize the conditions of the chosen neuron. Since the adversary does not know ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D}, it can only approximate Eq. (4) for all of its observed data samples xğ‘¥x that are different from tğ‘¡t (i.e., xâ‰ tğ‘¥ğ‘¡x\neq t and xâˆ‰ğ’Ÿğ‘¥ğ’Ÿx\notin\mathcal{D}). However, that makes Eq. (4) infeasible due to the linearity of the functions âˆ‘j=1dWiâ€‹jâ€‹tjsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘Šğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘—\sum_{j=1}^{d}W_{ij}t_{j} and âˆ‘j=1dWiâ€‹jâ€‹xjsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘—1ğ‘‘subscriptğ‘Šğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—\sum_{j=1}^{d}W_{ij}x_{j}, as shown in Appendix A.

To address this issue, we introduce non-linearity into the equation. To do so, instead of relying on the first layer, the adversary can choose a neuron in the second fully-connected layer such that the neuron is activated only by the target data sample tğ‘¡t, and not activated by any other data samples xâ‰ tğ‘¥ğ‘¡x\neq t. Let us denote hâˆˆâ„râ„superscriptâ„ğ‘Ÿh\in\mathbb{R}^{r} as the weight vector of the chosen neuron in the second layer, the attack is successful if we can find (h,W)â„ğ‘Š(h,W) such that:

{âˆ‘i=1rhiâ€‹ReLUâ¡(âˆ‘j=1dWiâ€‹jâ€‹tj)>0âˆ‘i=1rhiâ€‹ReLUâ¡(âˆ‘j=1dWiâ€‹jâ€‹xj)â‰¤0,âˆ€xâ‰ t\left\{\begin{aligned} &\sum_{i=1}^{r}h_{i}\operatorname{ReLU}(\sum_{j=1}^{d}W_{ij}t_{j})>0\\ &\sum_{i=1}^{r}h_{i}\operatorname{ReLU}(\sum_{j=1}^{d}W_{ij}x_{j})\leq 0,\quad\forall x\neq t\end{aligned}\right. Next, we sample a dataset ğ’³âˆ¼ğ”»msimilar-toğ’³superscriptğ”»ğ‘š\mathcal{X}\sim\mathbb{D}^{m}, in which we assign a label 111 for the target data sample tğ‘¡t and label 00 for all other data samples xâˆˆğ’³âˆ–tğ‘¥ğ’³ğ‘¡x\in\mathcal{X}\setminus t. After that, we train the chosen neuron using cross-entropy loss. The key idea is that the training process tries to make sâ€‹(t)=1ğ‘ ğ‘¡1s(t)=1, and sâ€‹(x)=0ğ‘ ğ‘¥0s(x)=0 for xâ‰ tğ‘¥ğ‘¡x\neq t. When sâ€‹(t)>0.5ğ‘ ğ‘¡0.5s(t)>0.5, it means that hâ‹…ReLUâ¡(Wâ€‹t)>0â‹…â„ReLUğ‘Šğ‘¡0h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(Wt)>0; otherwise, when sâ€‹(x)<0.5ğ‘ ğ‘¥0.5s(x)<0.5, we have hâ‹…ReLUâ¡(Wâ€‹x)<0â‹…â„ReLUğ‘Šğ‘¥0h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(Wx)<0 and that conforms to Eq. When the adversary receives the gradient GğºG, it can observe the gradient of that chosen neuron to determine whether the target data sample tğ‘¡t is in the training set ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D} (tâˆˆğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ’Ÿt\in{\cal D}) or not, as discussed in the previous section. In particular, the adversary extracts the gradient of the chosen neuron, denoted by gtsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡g_{t}, from GğºG and sees whether gtsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡g_{t} is non-zero. If gtsubscriptgtg_{t} is zero, the adversary predicts that the target data sample ttt is not in the training set ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D} (i.e., tâˆ‰ğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ’Ÿt\notin{\cal D}). This is because the chosen neuron was not activated during the gradient computation on the training set ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D}. Otherwise, if gtsubscriptgtg_{t} is non-zero, then the adversary predicts that the target data sample ttt is in the training set ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D} (i.e., tâˆˆğ’Ÿğ‘¡ğ’Ÿt\in{\cal D}).

Fig. 2 shows a design of the adversary ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A} according to the threat model in Fig. 1. Note that our attack strategy only modifies the parameters of 1 chosen neuron in the second layer and rğ‘Ÿr associated neurons in the first layer. That makes our attack feasible by enabling us to make a minimal change to the model parameters, and the attack can be carried out within one FL training iteration.

4 AMI ATTACK UNDER LDP WITH CERTIFIED GUARANTEE OF SUCCESS

LDP is generally regarded as an effective defense against privacy inference attacks given its rigorous privacy protection compared with other approaches [Wagh etÂ al., 2021]. To tolerate such mechanisms, our AMI attack exploits the correlation among input features captured through a non-linear decision boundary to distinguish the target data sample tğ‘¡t from others (Eq. 5) under LDP protection. If LDP-preserving noise is insufficient to break this correlation (i.e., large privacy budgets Îµğœ€\varepsilon), clientsâ€™ local data will be at risk of our AMI attack. Meanwhile, large privacy-preserving noise (i.e., small privacy budgets Îµğœ€\varepsilon) can significantly damage the model utility. In FL, it is challenging for clients to identify suitable privacy budgets given their limited local training data. Therefore, they usually rely on the server to provide the privacy budget Îµğœ€\varepsilon and the LDP-preserving mechanism â„³â„³\mathcal{M}. That increases the risk of exposing their local training data to a dishonest server under our AMI attack. We focus on shedding light on the fundamental trade-offs between Îµğœ€\varepsilon-LDP protection, model utility, and privacy risk with a certified bound for our AMI attack to be successful.

Each client independently perturbs every training data sample in their local training data ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D} using an LDP-preserving mechanism â„³â„³\mathcal{M} (Def. 1) to obtain a randomized local training set ğ’Ÿâ€²=â„³â€‹(ğ’Ÿ,Îµ)={â„³â€‹(x,Îµ)}xâˆˆğ’Ÿsuperscriptğ’Ÿâ€²â„³ğ’Ÿğœ€subscriptâ„³ğ‘¥ğœ€ğ‘¥ğ’Ÿ{\cal D}^{\prime}=\mathcal{M}({\cal D},\varepsilon)=\{\mathcal{M}(x,\varepsilon)\}_{x\in{\cal D}}. The client sends the gradients derived from the randomized training set G=âˆ‡Î¸â„’â€‹(ğ’Ÿâ€²,Î¸)ğºsubscriptâˆ‡ğœƒâ„’superscriptğ’Ÿâ€²ğœƒG=\nabla_{\theta}\mathcal{L}({\cal D}^{\prime},\theta) to the server. The mechanism â„³â„³\mathcal{M} and the privacy budget Îµğœ€\varepsilon are known to the adversary ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}, thus, the adversary function in Eq. (2) is re-defined under LDP context as ğ’œLâ€‹Dâ€‹Pğ”»,â„³:t,G,Îµâ†’{0,1}:subscriptsuperscriptğ’œğ”»â„³ğ¿ğ·ğ‘ƒâ†’ğ‘¡ğºğœ€01\mathcal{A}^{\mathbb{D},\mathcal{M}}_{LDP}:t,G,\varepsilon\rightarrow\{0,1\}. We enhance the threat model to reflect the use of LDP in Fig. 3.

Attack Strategy.

Given the gradients GğºG computed on LDP-perturbed data ğ’Ÿâ€²superscriptğ’Ÿâ€²{\cal D}^{\prime}, applying the same attack strategy that was discussed in Section 3.2 would not work effectively. Suppose that the target sample tğ‘¡t is in ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D}, and that the adversary were able to train a neuron that is activated only by the target sample tğ‘¡t, i.e., hâ‹…ReLUâ¡(Wâ€‹t)>0â‹…â„ReLUğ‘Šğ‘¡0h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(Wt)>0 and hâ‹…ReLUâ¡(Wâ€‹x)<0â‹…â„ReLUğ‘Šğ‘¥0h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(Wx)<0 for xâ‰ tğ‘¥ğ‘¡x\neq t. However, it is very likely that tğ‘¡t is not in the randomized local training set ğ’Ÿâ€²superscriptğ’Ÿâ€²{\cal D}^{\prime} since tğ‘¡t was randomized under LDP. As the client uses ğ’Ÿâ€²superscriptğ’Ÿâ€²{\cal D}^{\prime} for gradients computation, the chosen neuron may remain inactivated, i.e., hâ‹…ReLUâ¡(Wâ‹…â„³â€‹(t,Îµ))<0â‹…â„ReLUâ‹…ğ‘Šâ„³ğ‘¡ğœ€0h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(W\cdot\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon))<0. Hence, the attack fails to infer the correct membership of tğ‘¡t.

Therefore, it is necessary for the adversary to ensure that the chosen neuron is activated only by the randomized target sample â„³â€‹(t,Îµ)â„³ğ‘¡ğœ€\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon). Similar to Eq. (5), we formulate this observation as finding (h,W)â„ğ‘Š(h,W) such that:

{hâ‹…ReLUâ¡(Wâ€‹â„³â€‹(t,Îµ))>0hâ‹…ReLUâ¡(Wâ€‹x)â‰¤0,âˆ€xâ‰ â„³â€‹(t,Îµ)\left\{\begin{aligned} &h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(W\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon))>0\\ &h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(Wx)\leq 0,\quad\forall x\neq\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon)\end{aligned}\right. (7)

To develop an effective attack for Eq. To achieve our goal, we strengthen our attack by generating a set ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T} of lğ‘™l perturbations â„³â€‹(t,Îµ)â„³ğ‘¡ğœ€\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon), that is, invoking â„³â€‹(t,Îµ)â„³ğ‘¡ğœ€\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon) lğ‘™l times with independent draws of LDP-preserving noise. Next, we sample a training set ğ’³âˆ¼ğ”»msimilar-toğ’³superscriptğ”»ğ‘š\mathcal{X}\sim\mathbb{D}^{m} such that ğ’³âˆ©ğ’¯=âˆ…ğ’³ğ’¯\mathcal{X}\cap\mathcal{T}=\emptyset. Then, we assign label 111 for samples in ğ’¯ğ’¯\mathcal{T} (which contains randomized versions of tğ‘¡t) and label 00 for samples in ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X}. Finally, we train the chosen neuron using cross-entropy loss. The remaining steps follow Section 3.2. Fig. 4 shows the design of the adversary ğ’œLâ€‹Dâ€‹Psubscriptğ’œğ¿ğ·ğ‘ƒ\mathcal{A}_{LDP} with respect to the threat model in Fig. 3.

Certified Guarantee of Success for AMI.

{ğ”¼â€‹[vâ€‹(t)]>0ğ”¼â€‹[vâ€‹(x)]â‰¤0,xâ‰ â„³â€‹(t,Îµ)\left\{\begin{aligned} &\mathbb{E}\big{[}v(t)\big{]}>0\\ &\mathbb{E}\big{[}v(x)\big{]}\leq 0,\quad x\neq\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon)\end{aligned}\right. (8)

By replacing the bounds in Eqs. (9) and (10) to the expectations in Eq. (8), we derive the certified guarantee so that Eq.Â (8) holds as in Theorem 11.

Theorem 1.

(Certified Guarantee Condition) Suppose that clients in FL apply the LDP-preserving â„³â€‹(â‹…,Îµ)â„³â‹…ğœ€\mathcal{M}(\cdot,\varepsilon) to their local data. ğ”¼^lâ€‹bâ€‹[vâ€‹(t)]superscript^ğ”¼ğ‘™ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘£ğ‘¡\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{lb}\big{[}v(t)\big{]} and ğ”¼^uâ€‹bâ€‹[vâ€‹(x)]superscript^ğ”¼ğ‘¢ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘£ğ‘¥\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{ub}\big{[}v(x)\big{]}, computed as in Eqs.Â 9 and 10, are the (1âˆ’Î´)1ğ›¿(1-\delta)-confidence lower and upper bounds, respectively. The AMI attack ğ’œLâ€‹Dâ€‹Pğ”»,â„³subscriptsuperscriptğ’œğ”»â„³ğ¿ğ·ğ‘ƒ\mathcal{A}^{\mathbb{D},\mathcal{M}}_{LDP} is successful in inferring the membership of the target sample tğ‘¡t in ğ”»ğ”»\mathbb{D} if the following condition is satisfied:

{ğ”¼^lâ€‹bâ€‹[vâ€‹(t)]>0ğ”¼^uâ€‹bâ€‹[vâ€‹(x)]â‰¤0,xâ‰ â„³â€‹(t,Îµ)\left\{\begin{aligned} &\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{lb}\big{[}v(t)\big{]}>0\\ &\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{ub}\big{[}v(x)\big{]}\leq 0,\quad x\neq\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon)\end{aligned}\right. (11)

Proof of Theorem 11 is in Appendix B. At the attack time, we implement a certified guarantee of success as a search to return the minimal privacy budget Îµğœ€\varepsilon and broken probability Î´ğ›¿\delta so that the condition in Theorem 11 holds, as follows:

Corollary 1.

Given a well-trained model fÎ¸subscriptğ‘“ğœƒf_{\theta} and the target sample tğ‘¡t, the AMI attack ğ’œLâ€‹Dâ€‹Pğ”»,â„³subscriptsuperscriptğ’œğ”»â„³ğ¿ğ·ğ‘ƒ\mathcal{A}^{\mathbb{D},\mathcal{M}}_{LDP} is guaranteed to be successful up to the privacy budget Îµâˆ—superscriptğœ€\varepsilon^{*} and the broken probability Î´âˆ—superscriptğ›¿\delta^{*} for which the condition in Theorem 11 checks out:

(Îµâˆ—,Î´âˆ—)=argminÎµ,Î´s.t.{ğ”¼^lâ€‹bâ€‹[hâ‹…ReLUâ¡(Wâ€‹â„³â€‹(t,Îµ))]>0ğ”¼^uâ€‹bâ€‹[hâ‹…ReLUâ¡(Wâ€‹x)]â‰¤0,xâ‰ â„³â€‹(t,Îµ)(\varepsilon^{*},~{}\delta^{*}){=}\arg\min_{\varepsilon,\delta}~{}\text{s.t.}~{}\left\{\begin{aligned} &\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{lb}\big{[}h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(W\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon))\big{]}>0\\ &\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{ub}\big{[}h\cdot\operatorname{ReLU}(Wx)\big{]}\leq 0,x{\neq}\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon)\end{aligned}\right. (12)

Since the mechanism â„³â€‹(â‹…)â„³â‹…\mathcal{M}(\cdot) and the privacy budget Îµğœ€\varepsilon are known to the adversary ğ’œğ’œ\mathcal{A}, we only do a line search to find the minimal Î´ğ›¿\delta for a given Îµâˆ—superscriptğœ€\varepsilon^{*}.

5 EVALUATION

This section validates the effectiveness of our AMI attack by gauging its success rate. We particularly focus on evaluating how well it performs under LDP protection. Our implementation of the attack is available at https://github.com/trucndt/ami.

Experimental Settings.

We evaluate AMI attack with three benchmark datasets, including CIFAR-10 [Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009], ImageNet [Deng etÂ al., 2009], and CelebA [Liu etÂ al., 2015]. Each dataset includes a training set and a validation set. The training set is used to sample the local training set ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D} in the threat model (Figs. 1 and 3), while the validation set is used as the sampled set ğ’³ğ’³\mathcal{X} of the adversary. Our experiment follows the security game in Figs. 1 and 3, and the success rate is calculated using Eq. (3) after executing the game 10,000 times. The batch size |ğ’Ÿ|ğ’Ÿ|{\cal D}| is chosen to be 20 for the CelebA dataset according to its specification (i.e., 20 face images per person). As in [Fowl etÂ al., 2021, Boenisch etÂ al., 2021, Geiping etÂ al., 2020], we set |ğ’Ÿ|ğ’Ÿ|{\cal D}| to 64 and 100 for the ImageNet and CIFAR-10 datasets, respectively. We modify r=1,000ğ‘Ÿ1000r=1,000 neurons in the first layer and 1 neuron in the second layer to carry out AMI attacks. Further details on the experimental settings can be found in Appendix D.

To realize â„³â„³\mathcal{M} in Fig.Â 3, we use two different LDP mechanisms: OME [Lyu etÂ al., 2020] and BitRand [Lai etÂ al., 2021]. These mechanisms add LDP noises to the embeddings of data samples. Such embeddings are obtained via a pre-trained Resnet-18 model which results in feature vectors of 512 dimensions [He etÂ al., 2016]. We show the results when using BitRand in this section and refer the readers to Appendix D for the results on OME. A background on BitRand and OME is provided in Appendix C.

Attack Performance without LDP.

In three datasets, our attack achieves near 100% success rate. The key reason behind this impressive success rate is that our attack strategy can easily train the chosen neuron to satisfy the attack objective, i.e., Eq. (5). Intuitively, the problem formulation in Eq. (5) is equivalent to finding a decision boundary over-fitting to tğ‘¡t in a way that can distinguish tğ‘¡t against all other samples. As a result, increasing the number of neurons in the first layer (rğ‘Ÿr) helps improve the attack performance, as it makes the model more over-fitting. In our experiments, we can achieve a 100% success rate with as few as 5 neurons (r=5ğ‘Ÿ5r=5) in the first layer. We refer the readers to Appendix D for further analysis of this scenario as we focus the rest of this section on evaluating the attack under LDP.

Attack Performance under LDP.

Fig. 5 shows that our attack introduces severe privacy risk to clientsâ€™ local training data through strong attack success rates under LDP protection. Large privacy budgets Îµğœ€\varepsilon (e.g., Îµâ‰¥5ğœ€5\varepsilon\geq 5) does minimal to defend against our AMI attack. Across all three datasets, the model accuracy on the legitimate classification task remains acceptable given Îµâ‰¥5ğœ€5\varepsilon\geq 5. However, our attack imposes a severely high success rate (â‰¥0.77absent0.77\geq 0.77), which approaches a near perfect success rate of 0.990.990.99 with Îµâ‰¥9ğœ€9\varepsilon\geq 9. When we reduce the privacy budget (Îµâˆˆ[3,4]ğœ€34\varepsilon\in[3,4]), our attack still maintains a success rate of at least 0.67, 0.58, and 0.62, on CelebA, ImageNet, and CIFAR-10, respectively. With very low Îµğœ€\varepsilon (Îµâˆˆ[1,2]ğœ€12\varepsilon\in[1,2]), the model accuracy is severely damaged.

Furthermore, Fig. 5 depicts the TPR and TNR of our attack. Recall that TPR denotes how well the attack detects the presence of the target sample tğ‘¡t in the training data ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D}, and TNR measures the ability to detect the absence of tğ‘¡t. From the result, we can see that our attack has high TPR across all scenarios, which means it is sensitive to detecting the case where tâˆˆDğ‘¡ğ·t\in D. Moreover, our TNR is greater than 0.5 indicating the capability of discerning the absence of tğ‘¡t in the training data (except for the ImageNet dataset at Îµâ‰¤4ğœ€4\varepsilon\leq 4).

Training the Chosen Neuron under LDP.

Training the chosen neuron is equivalent to determining a decision boundary that can distinguish the target sample (and its randomized variants) from any other samples. Fig. 6 visualizes how the samples in the training set ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D} are distributed using t-SNE [VanÂ der Maaten and Hinton, 2008]. At Îµ=10ğœ€10\varepsilon=10, Fig. 6(a) shows that the t-SNE algorithm is able to group together the target sample tğ‘¡t and its randomized variants. This is because the LDP mechanism imposes a small amount of noise such that tğ‘¡t and its randomized variants â„³â€‹(t,Îµ)â„³ğ‘¡ğœ€\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon) closely resemble one another. Hence, t-SNE models these by nearby points. Therefore, it is easy for our attack to train a neuron that can distinguish â„³â€‹(t,Îµ)â„³ğ‘¡ğœ€\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon) from other samples, resulting in an attack success rate of about 0.99 as shown in Fig. 5.

At Îµ=5ğœ€5\varepsilon=5, Fig. 6(c) shows that â„³â€‹(t,Îµ)â„³ğ‘¡ğœ€\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon) blends into other samples, meaning that t-SNE is unable to group together the randomized variants of tğ‘¡t as in the previous Fig. 6(a). This is because the mechanism â„³â€‹(â‹…,Îµ)â„³â‹…ğœ€\mathcal{M}(\cdot,\varepsilon) imposes a high amount of noise at Îµ=5ğœ€5\varepsilon=5, so that all randomized variants â„³â€‹(t,Îµ)â„³ğ‘¡ğœ€\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon) no longer closely resemble one another. This makes the task of finding the decision boundary between â„³â€‹(t,Îµ)â„³ğ‘¡ğœ€\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon) and other samples more difficult. Nevertheless, our AMI attack can still attain a success rate of 0.80 (Fig.Â  5).

Certified Guarantee of Success.

Given a privacy budget Îµâˆˆ[1,10]ğœ€110\varepsilon\in[1,10], in order to check the certified guanrantee conditions as in Theorem 11, we obtain the the lower and upper bounds ğ”¼^lâ€‹bâ€‹[vâ€‹(t)]superscript^ğ”¼ğ‘™ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘£ğ‘¡\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{lb}\big{[}v(t)\big{]} and ğ”¼^uâ€‹bâ€‹[vâ€‹(x)]superscript^ğ”¼ğ‘¢ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘£ğ‘¥\hat{\mathbb{E}}^{ub}\big{[}v(x)\big{]} (Eqs.Â 9 and 10) by using 4,00040004,000 Îµğœ€\varepsilon-LDP target samples â„³â€‹(t,Îµ)â„³ğ‘¡ğœ€\mathcal{M}(t,\varepsilon) and all Îµğœ€\varepsilon-LDP non-target samples â„³â€‹(x,Îµ)â„³ğ‘¥ğœ€\mathcal{M}(x,\varepsilon) from the validation set of each dataset. Here we use BitRand [Lai etÂ al., 2021] as the â„³â€‹(â‹…,Îµ)â„³â‹…ğœ€\mathcal{M}(\cdot,\varepsilon) mechanism for the embeddings since BitRand is designed and well-suited for randomizing the embeddings.

Fig.Â 7 shows the certified guarantee of success for the CelebA, ImageNet, and CIFAR-10 datasets. We can derive certified guarantee of success for our AMI attack given Îµâ‰¥1ğœ€1\varepsilon\geq 1 with a small broken probability 10âˆ’8superscript10810^{-8}. For rigorous privacy budgets, e.g., Îµâ‰¤3ğœ€3\varepsilon\leq 3, the output of the chosen neuron for both the target and non-target samples approaches the borderline associated with vâ€‹(â‹…)=0ğ‘£â‹…0v(\cdot)=0 (i.e., the dotted green lines), indicating a higher chance for AMI attacks to be failed given a broken probability Î´ğ›¿\delta. When the privacy budget Îµğœ€\varepsilon increases, the output of the chosen neuron fits well with the attack objective. As a result, the expected value of the chosen neuron departs from the borderline, i.e., more positive given the target samples (i.e., the solid red lines) and more negative given the non-target samples (i.e., the solid blue lines). That implies a better attack success rate. Also, we observed that the overlapping area between the two distributions of the target samples and the non-target samples reduce significantly, which is consistent with our certified guarantee of success (Fig.Â 10, Appendix D) and our empirical results in Fig.Â 5.

6 RELATED WORK

Membership inference (MI) is one of the most fundamental privacy problems in machine learning [Carlini etÂ al., 2022]. Several research has been carried out to convey the practical consequences of MI attacks [Backes etÂ al., 2016, Pyrgelis etÂ al., 2018] and analyze the modelsâ€™ vulnerability to MI [Carlini etÂ al., 2019, Song and Mittal, 2021]. Along this direction, multiple MI attacks have been proposed in which the attacker only queries the model or observes its parameters to conduct the attacks [Shokri etÂ al., 2017, Salem etÂ al., 2019, Carlini etÂ al., 2022]. Such attacks can be straightforwardly adapted to FL in which the central server is a passive adversary who tries to infer the membership information of clientsâ€™ private data via inspecting their local modelsâ€™ parameters [Nguyen and Thai, 2022, Melis etÂ al., 2019]. Recently, an AMI attack in FL proposed by [Nasr etÂ al., 2019] considers a dishonest server that can interfere with the FL training protocol. However, this attack must be repeated in multiple training iterations to attain a high success rate. Furthermore, LDP has been shown to be an effective defense against these attacks [Rahman etÂ al., 2018, Bernau etÂ al., 2021, Gu etÂ al., 2022].

Our work proposes a new AMI attack in FL where the dishonest server can maliciously modify the model weights to its advantage. We have proposed a strategy that results in minimal modifications to the model and can be executed in only one training iteration. More importantly, our attack can maintain a strong success rate even when the clientsâ€™ data are protected by an LDP mechanism.

7 CONCLUSION AND DISCUSSION

In this paper, we have introduced a formal threat model for our AMI attack with dishonest FL servers, showing a more realistic privacy threat. Accordingly, we have proposed a new active membership inference (AMI) attack, exploiting the correlation among data features through a non-linear decision boundary. AMI attacks can achieve high success rates even under LDP protection, confirmed by both theoretical analysis and experimental evaluations. From this attack, our research has demonstrated that current implementations of FL provide virtually no privacy protection for clients.

With such a strong AMI attack, our future work would focus on the defenses. We discuss some challenges in devising such a solution as follows.

Noisy gradients with DPSGD. A potential defense against our attack is to let clients add DP noise to their gradients using DPSGD [Abadi etÂ al., 2016] before sending them to the server, hindering the attacker from knowing the true value of the chosen neuronâ€™s gradient. However, recent work [Boenisch etÂ al., 2021, TramÃ¨r and Boneh, 2021] suggests that using DPSGD makes it impossible to train a good model for datasets like CIFAR-10 or ImageNet. Furthermore, even if DPSGD is used, the attacker can still circumvent it by aggregating the noisy gradients over multiple FL iterations and potentially cancelling out the added DP noise. A detailed analysis on this can be found in Appendix E.

Detecting Malicious Weights is Challenging. The hardness in detecting malicious weights can be evaluated by examining the difference between malicious weights and normal weights (i.e., the weights that could be obtained from an honest server). Fig. 14 (Appendix) shows the distribution of the normal weights together with the distribution of the malicious weights when attacking under LDP protection at Îµ=2,3,ğœ€23\varepsilon=2,3, and 555, and they largely resemble one another. Fig. 8 shows the 4 distributions using their respective kernel density estimation (KDE), which is used to visualize the shape of a data distribution, and represent the data using a continuous probability density curve. We can see that the malicious weights do not result in any abnormal distribution, making it indistinguishable from normal weights. This implies that, by observing the distribution of model weights, it is infeasible to determine whether the model weights have been modified maliciously by our attack.

Consequently, Theorem 11 holds.

Appendix C OME [Lyu etÂ al., 2020] AND BITRAND [Lai etÂ al., 2021]

Apart from applying LDP-preserving mechanisms in real values of inputs or gradients [Warner, 1965, Zhao etÂ al., 2020, Wang etÂ al., 2019], there is a line of work introducing LDP-preserving mechanisms to inputs or embedding features [Lai etÂ al., 2021, Lyu etÂ al., 2020, Arachchige etÂ al., 2019]. In these mechanisms, they encode the original data or embedding features into binary vectors, then apply the LDP mechanisms on top of the binary vectors, before training the local models.

In OME, each bit iğ‘–i is randomized differently depending on whether it is the odd or even bit or it is bit 00 or 111, as follows:

where Îµğœ€\varepsilon the total privacy budget.

This mechanism is similar to the Utility enhancing randomization (UER) mechanism (Theorem III.4 [Arachchige etÂ al., 2019]). As shown in [Arachchige etÂ al., 2019, Lyu etÂ al., 2020], model accuracy is almost constant although Îµğœ€\varepsilon is changed.

However, existing LDP mechanisms suffer from the curse of privacy composition in which excessive privacy budgets are consumed proportionally to the large dimensions of input or embedded features [Arachchige etÂ al., 2019], gradients [Zhao etÂ al., 2020, Wang etÂ al., 2019], and training rounds [Zhao etÂ al., 2020, Wang etÂ al., 2019], causing loose privacy protection or inferior model accuracy [Wagh etÂ al., 2021].

To mitigate the curse of privacy composition and to optimize the trade-off among privacy and model utility, [Lai etÂ al., 2021] introduce bit-aware term i%â€‹llpercentğ‘–ğ‘™ğ‘™\frac{i\%l}{l} and a temperature Î±ğ›¼\alpha for better control of the randomization probabilities. In BitRand, the randomization probabilities are adaptively randomized such that â€œbits with a more substantial impactâ€ on model utility will have â€smaller randomization probabilities (less noisy)â€ and vice-versa under the same privacy budget, as follows:

(23)

where vxâ€‹(i)âˆˆ{0,1}subscriptğ‘£ğ‘¥ğ‘–01v_{x}(i)\in\{0,1\} is the value of vxsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¥v_{x} at the bit iğ‘–i, vxâ€²subscriptsuperscriptğ‘£â€²ğ‘¥v^{\prime}_{x} is the perturbed vector created by randomizing all the bits in vxsubscriptğ‘£ğ‘¥v_{x}, Îµğœ€\varepsilon is a privacy budget, and Î±ğ›¼\alpha is a parameter bounded with 0<Î±â‰¤Îµ+râ€‹l2â€‹râ€‹âˆ‘i=0lâˆ’1expâ¡(2â€‹Îµlâ€‹i%â€‹l)0ğ›¼ğœ€ğ‘Ÿğ‘™2ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–0ğ‘™12ğœ€ğ‘™percentğ‘–ğ‘™0<\alpha\leq\sqrt{\frac{\varepsilon+rl}{2r\sum_{i=0}^{l-1}\exp(2\frac{\varepsilon}{l}i\%l)}}. Appendix D ADDITIONAL EXPERIMENTS

This section provides more details on the experimental settings, and presents additional experiments.

Settings.

Our experiments in this paper are implemented using Python 3.8 and conducted on a single GPU-assisted compute node that is installed with a Linux 64-bit operating system. The allocated resources include 8 CPU cores (AMD EPYC 7742 model) with 2 threads per core, and 60GB of RAM. The node is also equipped with 8 GPUs (NVIDIA DGX A100 SuperPod model), with 80GB of memory per GPU.

The model accuracies in Figs. 5 and 11 are measured by evaluating the model on legitimate classification tasks. For the CelebA dataset [Liu etÂ al., 2015], the task is to classify whether a person is smiling or not based on face images. With regard to the CIFAR-10 dataset [Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009], we use its original classification task with 10 classes. For the ImageNet dataset [Deng etÂ al., 2009], we extract a subset of 10 classes: tench, English springer, cassette player, chain saw, church, French horn, garbage truck, gas pump, golf ball, and parachute111https://github.com/fastai/imagenette. Then, we evaluate the model performance on classifying those 10 classes.

To obtain the feature embeddings of data samples, we use the pre-trained Resnet-18 model from Img2Vec222https://github.com/christiansafka/img2vec.

Attack performance without LDP.

In this setting, the attack strategy in Fig. 2 requires the attacker to train the malicious parameters h,Wâ„ğ‘Šh,W, which takes multiple local training epochs. Fig. 9 shows the attack success rate per local epoch with 2,000 neurons in the first layer (r=2,000ğ‘Ÿ2000r=2,000). As can be seen, over time, the attack success rate reaches 100% across all three datasets. Table 1 shows the average number of local training epochs needed to train those parameters to achieve the 100% success rate, as we vary rğ‘Ÿr. We observe that increasing rğ‘Ÿr helps the attacker find the optimal parameters h,Wâ„ğ‘Šh,W faster. For CIFAR-10, with r=2,000ğ‘Ÿ2000r=2,000 neurons in the first layer, the attacker can easily train h,Wâ„ğ‘Šh,W within 50 epochs.

To understand the reason behind this behavior, we note that training h,Wâ„ğ‘Šh,W in this attack strategy is equivalent to finding a non-linear decision boundary that overfits to the target sample tğ‘¡t (Eq. 5), thereby distinguishing the target sample tğ‘¡t from any other samples. Hence, increasing rğ‘Ÿr raises the chance of over-fitting which, in turn, shortens the time to find h,Wâ„ğ‘Šh,W. Furthermore, Table 1 indicates that as few as r=5ğ‘Ÿ5r=5 neurons are needed to attain the 100% success rate, albeit the longer training time.

Attack performance under LDP.

To shed light into how the privacy budget Îµğœ€\varepsilon in the LDP mechanism, i.e., BitRand, affects the AMI success rate, we visualize the distribution of the values of the chosen neuron associated with the target and non-target samples. In Fig.Â 10(a), with rigorous privacy budget (e.g., Îµ=1ğœ€1\varepsilon=1), the mean values of the chosen neuron is positive given the target samples and negative given the non-target samples. However, there is a notable overlap in the two distributions of the target samples (i.e., red distribution) and the non-target samples (i.e., blue distribution). This makes the attack difficult in distinguishing the target and non-target samples, based on the value of the chosen neuron. Consequently, the attack success rate is moderate. On the other hand, when Îµğœ€\varepsilon increases (Figs.Â 10(b)-10(d)), the distribution of the target samples shift to the right, meanwhile the distribution of the non-target samples shift to the left. The shifts result in a less overlap between the two distributions. As a result, when the privacy budget Îµğœ€\varepsilon increases, the attack success rate of AMI increases. We observe this phenomenon in all three datasets.

In addition to evaluating the attack under the BitRand mechanism in Section 5, Fig. 11 shows our attack performance under the OME mechanism [Lyu etÂ al., 2020]. First, we observe the same phenomenon of OME as in [Arachchige etÂ al., 2019, Lyu etÂ al., 2020] in which the model accuracy does not change much for Îµâˆˆ[1,10]ğœ€110\varepsilon\in[1,10]. Second, our attack maintains a severe success rate of about 90% for CelebA and CIFAR-10. More importantly, the attack success rate reaches more than 95% for ImageNet. These results demonstrate that our AMI attack remains very effective even with low privacy budget Îµğœ€\varepsilon when the training set ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D} is protected by the OME mechanism.

Fig.Â 12 shows the certified guarantee of success for the CelebA, ImageNet, and CIFAR-10 datasets when the LDP-preserving OME mechanism is used. We can derive a certified guarantee of success for our AMI attack given Îµâ‰¥1ğœ€1\varepsilon\geq 1 with a small broken probability 10âˆ’8superscript10810^{-8}. This result is consistent with our attack success rate reported in Fig.Â 11. In addition to the unaffected model accuracy and attack success rate, the effect of the privacy budget Îµğœ€\varepsilon is modest in the certified guarantee of success, given Îµâˆˆ[1,10]ğœ€110\varepsilon\in[1,10] used in OME.

Appendix E NOISY GRADIENTS WITH DPSGD

Aside from LDP where clients perturb their own local training data ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ{\cal D} before computing the gradients, another method is to let clients add DP noise to their gradients using DPSGD [Abadi etÂ al., 2016] before sending them to the server, hindering the attacker from knowing the true value of the chosen neuronâ€™s gradient gtsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡g_{t}. Nevertheless, recent work suggests that using DPSGD makes it impossible to train models with reasonable accuracy for datasets like CIFAR-10 or ImageNet, even in a non-distributed setting [Boenisch etÂ al., 2021, TramÃ¨r and Boneh, 2021].

Moreover, even when DPSGD is used to add noise to the gradients, we can leverage the fact that the FL training is done in multiple iterations to circumvent this DP noise. In [Abadi etÂ al., 2016], the DP noise is sampled from a zero-mean Gaussian distribution with a standard deviation of Ïƒ=2â€‹lnâ¡(1.25/Î´)Îµğœ21.25ğ›¿ğœ€\sigma=\frac{\sqrt{2\ln(1.25/\delta)}}{\varepsilon}, where Îµğœ€\varepsilon is the privacy budget and Î´ğ›¿\delta is a broken probability. However, as the noise is zero-mean, averaging the noise samples over multiple iterations will cancel out the noise and reveal the true value of the gradients. This is also referred to as the privacy composition problem in DP [Dwork etÂ al., 2014].

Specifically, denoting gt(i)â€²=gt+zisuperscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘–â€²subscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘§ğ‘–g_{t}^{(i)^{\prime}}=g_{t}+z_{i} (where ziâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,Ïƒ2â€‹ğˆ)similar-tosubscriptğ‘§ğ‘–ğ’©0superscriptğœ2ğˆz_{i}\sim{\cal N}(0,\sigma^{2}\mathbf{I})) as the noisy gradient of the chosen neuron at iteration iğ‘–i, the server can obtain the true gradient gtsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡g_{t} by averaging over multiple iterations, i.e., gt=1Pâ€‹âˆ‘i=1Pgt(i)â€²subscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡1ğ‘ƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘–1ğ‘ƒsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘–â€²g_{t}=\frac{1}{P}\sum_{i=1}^{P}g_{t}^{(i)^{\prime}}. From this gtsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘¡g_{t}, the attacker can determine whether the target sample was used in at least one of those iterations, following the same principle in Section 3. Fig. 13(a) shows the number of iterations needed to eliminate the DP noise. Previous work shows that training a neural network for CIFAR-10 up to a modest accuracy of 66.2% requires a privacy budget Îµâ‰¥7.53ğœ€7.53\varepsilon\geq 7.53 [TramÃ¨r and Boneh, 2021], hence we evaluate with Îµâ‰¥7.5ğœ€7.5\varepsilon\geq 7.5. When Îµâ‰¥8ğœ€8\varepsilon\geq 8, we need less than 100 iterations.

To reduce the number of iterations, we can increase the number of chosen neurons in the second layer, and average the noisy gradients over all of the chosen neurons. Simply speaking, having Kğ¾K chosen neurons would reduce the number of iterations by Kğ¾K-fold. Fig. 13(b) shows the number of iterations needed to eliminate the DP noise with multiple neurons. As can be seen, with only 4 chosen neurons, we only need less than 60 iterations to cancel out the DP noise at Îµ=7.5ğœ€7.5\varepsilon=7.5. With 8 chosen neurons, the noise can be canceled out within 10 iterations.
